subject: State: Drive: Update the State interface for Drive
commitMessage:
State: Drive: Update the State interface for Drive

The State interface will have the state of the Drive and transition
states.

Added RequestedDriveTransition, DriveState, and LastRebootTime
based off xyz.openbmc_project.State.BMC.

The RequestedDriveTransition allow actions like reset and powercycles.
For systems that does not support it, it is defaulted to `NotSupported`.

The current DriveState provides different available state the drive can
be in. The `UpdateInProgress` in DriveState can be used to replace
the current `Rebuilding`.

Required:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/sdbusplus/+/45142
for sdbusplus maxint uint64 support.

Change-Id: I5350de29554a0a0a41307f1f009d942135471abe
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1855438658857b355cfed500a54141fd28aaccda by Patrick Williams

The way you've implemented this, it implies that all storage controllers support reset, which probably isn't true.  You probably need to define a new interface for it that can be mixed with the storage controller.

yeah, that's probably right.

Should the interface be

xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/ResettableStorage.interface.yaml instead?

Just for context, this is for SSDs.

----

I will rename after resolving the other issues.

Done.

Moved this to Drive as it is more related.
I'm assuming you didn't mean command here?

I think meant it?

Like it is a command that reset storage device?

Could you explain what your concerns are?

Maybe its better with,

```
Result of triggering the reset storage command.
```
?
Ack
This should be using the Software Version interface already exists.

sounds good. 

So we can remove this. and when we add the d-bus object, Add the other interface instead?
mark as unresolved until I actually remove it.
Done

These are generally lower level than we'd publish on dbus.  Direct access to gpio is generally represented as more structured APIs that represent what the GPIOs actually do (light an LED, reset a device, ect).

yeah, I agree.

I am not sure how we want to approach this... since it hard to group all the different requirements that different hardware might have.

Is it better to have a methods and do all the hardware specific stuff there.

Like GetGPIO(),

Then in the class that inherent the API, it will have the list of GPIOs that it is in charged of with all different permission types.

Or is that bad design?
Ack
This seems very generic too.
same as previous comments. Use method instead?
Done
When you move these, better descriptions for all this stuff would be good.

yep, just initial draft for now. 

I was about to mark as WIP... I guess I can't even send out message like that. 😞
Ack
How do we deal with the existing State.Drive implementation(s) which do not currently implement these new properties?  How do we deal with hardware where some of these states are not supported?

I am not sure if I understand the question. I don't have a deep understanding of how d-bus works yet.

But I thought that a new properties does not required overrides. So we can just add new properties without affecting existing implementation?

I assume those drives would just return "None" as the response and the caller would be forced to handle it. The caller would also need to deal with sending "Reboot" and possible getting back "PowerCycle" if called during a powercycle.

I got the structure from BMC State in https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/BMC.interface.yaml.

I wonder how those are handled there.

oh, I think I misunderstood William's comment.

Yeah, it will return "None" by default (or NotSupported with the new change).

For,
```
The caller would also need to deal with sending "Reboot" and possible getting back "PowerCycle" if called during a powercycle.
```

Does the user care if it returns `PowerCycle` when we call `Reboot`? This just indicate failure right? if it does not match.
Ack
I suspect you need some 'errors' listed here at least to indicate the possibility of NotSupported.
does properties have error? I thought it was just methods?
I think you can just add a NotSupported transition to the enum to achieve the desired result.
I have added NotSupported as the default.
Ack
What if the hardware has no way to determine this?
maybe just default to 0?
That's what most other instances do (See boot time counter properties on systemd1), you should comment about that.
Done
This probably needs a NotSupported / Unknown state that is used by default
Done

I feel like this is a confusing way to word the description. It's just a monotonic counter since the last reboot event? How does the drive have a time reference? Is this converting the monotonic counter based on the BMC time?

I guess it does not need a reference. As you mentioned, it is just a counter.


Actually, I know why it is kind of weird. I got it from https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/BMC.interface.yaml. But that is using actual time instead of counter.

I'll update this to say. Maybe UptimeCounter.
Will be converted to EpochTime instead now. This way it should have a time reference. And what the times are sync to the is up to the system itself.

Sorry I didn't respond very quickly to this discussion.

I think I prefer the 'LastRebootTime' design direction instead because it keeps any time calculation contained within the provider.  I'm ok with indicating that an EpochTime of 0 or maxint indicates that it is unsupported.

Bonus points if you enhance sdbusplus:tools/sdbusplus/property.py to be able to express a uint64 to default as 'maxint'

sorry for the delay.


Ok, sounds good. yeah, having EpochTime reported as LastRebootTime is more readable/friendly to debug the infomraiton.

I'll change it.

---

I'll see if I can make the change for maxint to the property.py. It might be useful for this + other properties in the future.
the maxint support in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/sdbusplus/+/45142.
Default = Ready?  Do we need an Unknown?
yeah, I think default to Unknown is better. I will add it.
